(cont'd)

"Of more general concern is the possibility that the movement to introduce scientists (in particular, mathematical physicists) into the government of the country may receive support based on ignorance of the realities of the matter. What Whitehead did not foresee (he wrote before the first world war) was that civilisation would soon be concerned less with advancing administratively than with ensuring its own survival, so that operations of thought would need to be the rule rather than the exception. Government now demands, above all things after moral rectitude, intelligent thought, and it must be recognised that mathematical physicists are, of all our citizens, the least fitted to provide it ..."

(cont'd)
